Two-Way ANOVA Models

Two-way ANOVA


Goal:

Assess if the relationship between one categorical explanatory variable and the response differs based on the values of another categorical variable

Modeling Options

Additive Model

Interaction Model

What are we looking for?

Picking joint bandwidth of 0.838

Hypothesis Test Steps

Step 1: Fit an interaction model

Step 2: Decide if the interaction is necessary

  • If yes, then this is your model!
  • If no, go to step 3.

aov(rating ~ era * genre, data = movies) %>% 
  tidy()

Why did I use a * when fitting the model?

term df sumsq meansq statistic p.value
era 3 4.585917 1.528639 0.6592709 0.5811488
genre 1 4.190670 4.190670 1.8073510 0.1851456
era:genre 3 3.317977 1.105992 0.4769920 0.6997818
Residuals 48 111.296687 2.318681 NA NA

What would you decide?

Step 3: Fit an additive model

Step 4: Decide if each explanatory variable is necessary

aov(rating ~ era + genre, data = movies) %>% 
  tidy()
aov(rating ~ era + genre, data = movies) %>% 
  tidy() %>% 
  gt()
term df sumsq meansq statistic p.value
era 3 4.585917 1.528639 0.6801973 0.5682209
genre 1 4.190670 4.190670 1.8647194 0.1780739
Residuals 51 114.614663 2.247346 NA NA

What would you decide?

Step 5: Remove the variable with the largest p-value

aov(rating ~ genre, data = movies) %>% 
  tidy()
aov(rating ~ genre, data = movies) %>% 
  tidy() %>% 
  gt()
term df sumsq meansq statistic p.value
genre 1 4.677942 4.677942 2.12789 0.1504322
Residuals 54 118.713308 2.198395 NA NA

What would you decide?

Step 6: Fit a mean-only model

summarize(movies,
          mean_rating = mean(rating)
          )
# A tibble: 1  1
  mean_rating
        <dbl>
1        5.64

Brainstorm

where the relationship between a (categorical) explanatory variable and a (quantitative) response variable differs based on the levels of another explanatory variable.

Writing research questions for one-way and two-way ANOVA models!
